intro: Abronia fragrans f. elliptica, commonly known as the fragrant sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its compact, mat-forming growth habit and produces clusters of small, fragrant, white to pinkish flowers. The leaves are typically narrow and lance-shaped, often covered in fine hairs. This plant thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it well-suited for arid and semi-arid environments. Its ornamental value is enhanced by its aromatic foliage and showy blooms.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abronia fragrans f. elliptica is primarily native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is found in regions such as Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Sonora and Sinaloa. This plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments. It is commonly associated with desert scrub and chaparral habitats. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones where it can thrive in full sun and well-drained conditions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abronia fragrans f. elliptica was mainly introduced to the Pacific Northwest region of the United States. It is commonly found in moist, well-drained soils along stream banks and in forested areas. This plant is often cultivated in gardens for its attractive, fragrant flowers. It has been reported in several states including Oregon and Washington. However, it is considered a non-native species in these regions.
